awd_titl_txt: NSF/FDA Scholar In Residence: 3D Printed Biomaterials for MSC Attachment and Targeted Differentiation
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Fisher, John P.
Proposal: 1445700
Title: NSF/FDA Scholar In Residence: 3D Printed Biomaterials for MSC Attachment and Targeted Differentiation

Significance
The clinical promise of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine will likely depend upon a viable strategy for the isolation, culture, and delivery of stem cells. Therefore, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) must be on the forefront of stem cell biology. Although a variety of stem cell populations exist, autogenic and allogeneic mesenchymal stem cells are among the most widely investigated population owing to their ability to be readily differentiated into any of the mesodermal tissues, including bone, cartilage, fat, tendon, and ligament.  Currently an enriched population of MSCs is obtained by differential centrifugation and/or plastic adherence. While both of these methods yield an enriched MSC population, neither offers a means to isolate and subsequently culture MSCs in one step. Most critically, these methods are only useful for in vitro culture of MSCs. The PI proposes the development of a modified biomaterial that can capture, culture, and differentiate an enriched MSC population, resulting in phenotypically stable chondrocytes. The proposed work will allow the FDA to remain on the forefront of stem cell technologies, both in the techniques utilized in the development of biomaterials for regenerative medicine and the interaction of stem cells with novel biomaterials. Finally, this work will promote FDA?s regulatory role by developing the in-house expertise to evaluate stem cell based technologies.

Technical Description
Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs), a multipotent stem cell line, have tremendous therapeutic potential, as they are capable of differentiating into various lineages such as bone, adipose, and cartilage. However, MSCs represent only a fraction of the cells that are found in the bone marrow and adipose tissue and lack unique identifying markers, which increases the difficulty of isolation. The goal of this proposed work is to develop a tissue engineering strategy to characterize MSC isolation based on adhesion, and to mimic the specific adhesive interactions on the surface of a biodegradable biomaterial to capture, culture, and differentiate MSCs for engineered cartilage tissue applications. To this end, the PI proposes to develop a device that will allow for in vivo recruitment and enrichment of MSCs, as well as provide a simple method for in vitro capture of MSCs.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The NSF/FDA SIR project entitled, “3D Printed Biomaterials for MSC Attachment and Targeted Differentiation,” aims to explore the interaction of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) with 3D-Printed culture environmental cues. Herein specific objectives include exploiting cell surface interactions to purify MSCs from whole bone marrow cell populations and to investigate the impact of 3D environmental cues on MSC differentiation.

In working to accomplish our project objectives, we have made strides in each of the proposed aims. With regard to our first aim, we have successfully designed and implemented a 3D-printed scaffold restraint device. The capture device restrains whole bone marrow loaded 3D-printed scaffolds undergoing centrifugation to collect cells which have not attached to scaffolds. This allows for the investigation of the impact of 3D geometry on whole bone marrow purification by way of studying attached and non-attached populations after use of our developed centrifugation assay.

The cell capture device has also been utilized to accomplish the goals of our third                                       aim. We have investigated the adherence efficiency of various proteins to the device surface including laminin, collagen, gelatin, fibrinogen, and fibronectin. Efforts to chemically couple proteins to the distinct quadrant surfaces are ongoing. Herein, the goal is to characterize cell populations loaded onto the collection device based on their attachment efficiency to multiple proteins using the centrifugation assay. We are investigating cell surface receptor-protein interactions within whole bone marrow as well within the non-attached cell fractions collected as described in the previous section and the attached fraction of cells after enzymatic lifting from 3D-printed constructs.

With regard to Aim 2, our research group has further developed in-house decellularization protocols from a variety of tissues for coupling extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins to 3D-printed constructs. Specifically, we have developed protocols for dermis, adipose tissue, pericardium, placenta, and uterine and ovarian tissue. Similar to the results described for Aim 3, we have also physically adhered whole ECM mixtures to our cell capture device material and chemical adherence optimization is ongoing

Presentations:

Results have been shared at internal meetings including at the annual FDA science forum in May 2016 and May 2017.

Inventions:

We are in the process of submitting an invention disclosure with the University of Maryland Technology Transfer Office

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2018
Modified by: John P Fisher
